isis.stitle: T 444E Diesel Engine Diagnostics (NAVPAK) (1997) - SECTION 1.8: DIAGNOSTIC SOFTWARE SELF TEST OPERATION - CONTINUOUS SELF TEST

svcproc.title: CONTINUOUS MONITOR
svcproc.para: Diagnostics are performed by the Electronic Control Module (ECM) continuously to detect out of range, rationality and system faults

During the time that the key is "ON", if an input signal is "Out of Range" meaning the signal is either greater or lesser than what the signal range should be during normal operation, the ECM will record a "Fault". It will also monitor the operation of systems and will determine if they are working within a normal operational range (Rationality fault detection). If the ECM detects that a system falls outside a predetermined range, it will record and set a fault code.

During normal engine operation, the ECM automatically performs several tests to detect faults. When it has detected a fault, the ECM often invokes a fault management strategy to allow continued, though sometimes degraded, vehicle operation.

The ECM can also set codes associated with the injection control system on a continuous basis which is an improvement from previous systems in which specific diagnostic tests had to be performed in order to get the codes.
A "Fault" is an indication of a malfunction measured or monitored electronically. Sometimes "Faults" are referred to as "Codes."

"Codes" are three digit numbers assigned to Faults to indicate the source of the malfunction. Most Codes will indicate the source and the "Mode" of failure. The "Failure Mode" will indicate the signal reading, IE.; "Out of Range High", "Out of Range Low" or in Range fault.

During operation of the truck with the engine running, the ECM memory will also record "EVENT ENGINE HOURS". This feature records if the engine has been operated beyond maximum rpm, over heated (coolant temperature), low on coolant and/or experienced low oil pressure.

The standard Engine Events are Overspeed of the engine, referred to as Over RPM and excessive coolant temperature. Low oil pressure and low coolant level operation will also be monitored and recorded as "EVENT ENGINE HOURS", if the engine is equipped with the optional engine warning/shutdown system.
Engine events logged into the ECM memory are permanent and they can be retrieved with the Electronic Service Tool (EST).
